metadata.titleEn: 1 km grid datasets of human activity intensity in agricultural and pastoral areas of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau
metadata.description: As the “third pole” of the world, the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) is extremely ecologically sensitive and fragile while facing increasing human activities and overgrazing. In this study, eight types of spatial data were firstly selected, including grazing intensity, Night-Time Light, population density, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) density, the ratio of cultivated land, the slope of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), distance to road, and distance to town. Then, the entropy weight method was applied to determine the weight of each factor. Finally, the five-year interval human activity intensity data in 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010 and 2015 were made in the agricultural and pastoral areas of QTP through the spatial overlap method. By preparing the historical spatial datasets of human activity intensity, our study will help to explore the influence of human disturbance on the alpine ecosystems on the QTP and provide effective support for decision-making of government aiming at regional ecosystem management and sustainable development.
metadata.instructions: File name: human activity intensity data of each period is stored in TIFF format, and the file name is“ yyyy.tif ”Where yyyy is the year. Data reading mode: data can be opened by ArcGIS, QGIS, envi, and ERDAS.

literatureList.titleEn: A study of the impacts of urban expansion on vegetation primary productivity levels in the Jing-Jin-Ji region, based on nighttime light data.

background: In remote sensing application research, nighttime light remote sensing has become an important and rapidly developing branch that has garnered increasing attention from both natural science and socio-economic fields in recent years. Unlike traditional optical remote sensing satellites that acquire radiative information of surface objects, nighttime light remote sensing captures information on visible light and near-infrared electromagnetic waves emitted from the Earth's surface under cloud-free conditions at night. Compared to ordinary remote sensing satellite images, the nighttime light images record surface light intensity information that more directly reflects human activity differences, and thus are widely used in studies of urbanization processes, impervious surface extraction, spatial estimation of socio-economic indicators, assessment of major events, and ecological environment evaluation. Thanks to the capability of nighttime light remote sensing images for large-scale, long-term observation of the Earth's surface, their open data products can effectively support research on human activities and urbanization processes. In recent years, with the continuous enrichment of light remote sensing data products, particularly the emergence of the new generation of nighttime light data NPP/VIIRS (National Polar-Orbiting Partnership's Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite), the shortcomings of DMSP/OLS nighttime light data in terms of spatial resolution, temporal resolution, and radiometric resolution have been effectively addressed, greatly expanding the research directions and application fields of nighttime light data.
research objective: Based on this, the paper provides a detailed review of research findings related to nighttime light data over the past few decades, summarizing them from the perspectives of data processing and technical methods, as well as application research. Finally, the article identifies future research hotspots in three areas: multi-source data fusion, expansion of application fields, and short-term monitoring of surface lighting.
challenges: Currently, although the application research results based on nighttime light data are continuously accumulating, there are still shortcomings in the systematic summary and organization of these results, such as incomplete coverage and lack of timeliness. Existing review papers on nighttime light data research also have shortcomings in terms of timeliness and coverage.

background: After the Industrial Revolution, which began in the UK in the latter half of the eighteenth century, energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel consumption began to rise. As nations around the world started to develop their economies based on fossil fuel consumption, the stage was set for global warming and global environmental change. Electric power stations consume mostly fossil fuels and the night-time light emitted by human activity increases the consumption of electric power. Monitoring of electric power consumption and CO2 emission by a remote sensing device such as a satellite is an efficient method for observing at high resolution a wide area at a certain period of time.
research objective: A methodology is presented to accurately estimate electric power consumption from saturated night-time Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) Operational Linescan System (OLS) imagery using a stable light correction.
challenges: Despite these advances, two problems remain to be solved in conventional studies: When constructing the dataset for extracting the stable light there are some arbitrary characteristics: (a) half-year data with a limited influence of the sunlight were used; and (b) the cloud cover was assessed visually, and images with only a few clouds were used. There are many studies about the relationship between the area of the stable light and electric power consumption as well as the CO2 emission but only a few of them deal with the cumulative DNs of the stable light parameter.
methods: An area correction for the stable light image of DMSP/OLS for the year 1999 was performed and the build-up area rate data were used to clarify the intensity distribution characteristics of the stable light. Based on the spatial distribution characteristics of the stable light, the saturation light of the electric power supply area of Japan was corrected using a cubic regression equation. The regression between the correction calculations by the cubic regression equation and the statistical electric power consumption data was applied in Japan and also in China, India and 10 other Asian countries.
dataset: In this study, we used DMSP-F14/OLS-VIS 1999 data from the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Satellite Image Database System (SIDaB) of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Agriculture Information Resources System (AGROPEDIA). The 1999 data for electric power consumption were obtained from the Statistics Bureau of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Japan (2002).
findings: This study confirms that electric power consumption can be estimated with high precision from the stable light.

background: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic non-communicable diseases among the older adults worldwide. The 2017 China Diabetes Prevalence Survey showed that the prevalence of diabetes in the older adults aged ≥ 60 years was 30.0%, and China has the largest number of older adults with diabetes in the world. Various acute and chronic complications caused by diabetes seriously affect the health status and quality of life of the older adults. Frailty, an emerging global health burden, is a common geriatric syndrome. A meta-analysis of 21 studies from Western high-income countries showed the prevalence of frailty among community-dwelling older adults ranges from 4 to 59%, with an average prevalence of 11%, the pooled prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among community-dwelling older adults in China were 10 and 43%, respectively, leading to an increased risk of falls, disability, hospitalization, and death, as well as an independent predictor of higher healthcare expenditure among older adults. As populations age, diabetes and frailty are frequently co-occurring health outcomes, and both frailty and diabetes increase the risk of adverse outcomes in older adults. A meta-analysis showed that older adults with diabetes with frailty had significantly increased risks of hospitalization, disability, and death compared with older adults with diabetes who were not frail. Studies have shown that frailty was an important factor affecting the target level of blood glucose management in the older adults with diabetes. The International Position Statement on Frailty in Diabetes emphasized that the identification and assessment of frailty should be part of the routine management of people with diabetes. Compared with developed countries, the research on frailty in the older adults in China started relatively recently, there were few comprehensive studies on the prevalence and associated factors of frailty and pre-frailty among older adults with diabetes nationwide.
research objective: To investigate the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty and its associated factors in Chinese older adults with diabetes through a nationwide cross-sectional study.
challenges: Our study has several limitations. First, the data on diabetes were self-reported and might be subject to memory bias. Second, this was a cross-sectional study, so the causal relationship between diabetes and frailty was not analyzed.
methods: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. Subjects with diabetes were included in this study. Frailty index (FI), based on 33 potential deficits, was used to categorize individuals as robust, pre-frail, or frail.
dataset: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China.
findings: Our study found that frail patients with diabetes were older, were more likely to have been hospitalized in the past 1 year, were more likely to have ADL disability, and were more likely to have comorbidities than non-frail patients with diabetes. Our study also found that female, rural residency, illiterate, ethnic minority, widowed, living alone, financial difficulties, and very difficult medical reimbursement were associated with the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. Our study found significant regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. The prevalence of frailty in older adults with diabetes in northern China was higher than that in southern China.

Verification.Question: Is the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR) used to gather data on older adults with diabetes in China?

Concept Completion.Question: What factors are considered for assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's agricultural and pastoral areas?
Concept Completion.Answer: grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, rate of change in the normalized vegetation index NDVI, distance to roads, distance to settlements

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges exist in the application research of night-time light data?
Concept Completion.Answer: lack of comprehensive systematic summarization and organization of research outcomes, limited coverage, outdatedness of existing review papers

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how entropy weight method is used in determining the weights of factors for assessing human activity intensity in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: In the dataset related to human activity intensity in the Tibetan Plateau, the entropy weight method was employed to determine the weights of various factors such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, NDVI rate of change, distance from roads, and distance from settlements.

Example.Question: What is an example of a data collection method for assessing frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes in China?
Example.Answer: An example is the use of the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), which is a nationwide cross-sectional study involving a representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more, using the Frailty Index (FI) based on 33 potential deficits to categorize individuals.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the factors used to assess human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's agricultural and pastoral areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, rate of change of normalized vegetation index (NDVI), distance to roads, distance to settlements

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics make night-time light remote sensing a valuable tool for studying human activity differences and urbanization processes?
Feature Specification.Answer: visible light and near-infrared electromagnetic wave information, cloud-free conditions at night, reflects human activity differences

Feature Specification.Question: What methodological approach is used to determine the weights for factors reflecting human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Definition.Question: What does 'entropy weight method' mean in the context of assessing human activity intensity?
Definition.Answer: In the context of assessing human activity intensity, the 'entropy weight method' is a technique used to determine the weight of various factors that reflect human activity intensity, such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, and GDP density. This method helps to objectively assign importance to each factor based on their variability, ultimately contributing to a composite index that evaluates human activity intensity.

Definition.Question: What does 'stable light correction' mean in the context of estimating electric power consumption from satellite imagery?
Definition.Answer: In the context of estimating electric power consumption from satellite imagery, 'stable light correction' refers to a methodology for adjusting satellite data to account for saturation effects in night-time light images. This involves correcting the stable light imagery to more accurately estimate electric power consumption, by applying regression analyses or other statistical methods to correlate the light data with actual power consumption statistics.

Interpretation.Question: How can the entropy weight method be applied to determine the importance of various factors in assessing human activity intensity in agricultural and pastoral regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The entropy weight method can be used to assign weights to different factors by measuring the amount of disorder or uncertainty associated with each factor. In this context, factors like grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, and others are evaluated for their contribution to human activity intensity, allowing researchers to determine their relative importance and influence in the dataset.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in developing a spatial overlay method to create a multi-temporal dataset of human activity intensity, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in developing a spatial overlay method include ensuring consistency in data sources and resolution for each time period, managing data integration from different datasets, and addressing spatial misalignments. Addressing these challenges requires careful preprocessing of data, using standardized geographic projections, and employing data harmonization techniques to ensure compatibility and accuracy across different years in the dataset.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the selection of specific indicators such as grazing intensity and night-time light index in assessing human activity intensity in the Tibetan Plateau's agricultural and pastoral regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of these indicators is influenced by the ecological sensitivity and vulnerability of the Tibetan Plateau and the need to reflect human activity intensity. Factors like grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, and GDP density are chosen because they directly or indirectly represent the intensity of human activities and their impact on the ecosystem.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the entropy weighting method used to determine the weight of factors in human activity intensity datasets for the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The entropy weighting method is used because it provides an objective way to determine the importance of each factor based on the variability of the data. This method helps to quantify the contribution of each factor to human activity intensity, ensuring that the final dataset accurately reflects the spatial and temporal dynamics of human activities in the region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using entropy weighting for determining factor importance in human activity intensity assessments on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing entropy weighting for determining factor importance can provide a more balanced and unbiased assessment of human activity intensity by objectively assigning weights based on data variability. This method may lead to a more accurate reflection of the relative impact of different human activities, which can enhance the reliability of spatial overlay results in generating human activity intensity datasets for the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind evaluating human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's agricultural and pastoral areas over multiple time periods?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include exploring the impact of human interference on the plateau's alpine ecosystem and providing effective support for government decision-making in regional ecosystem management and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate multiple factors like grazing intensity and night-time light index in assessing human activity intensity?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating multiple factors like grazing intensity and night-time light index provides a comprehensive assessment of human activity intensity, which reflects the changes and impacts on ecological sensitivity and vulnerability in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of using entropic weight methods to determine the weight of factors in assessing human activity intensity?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of using entropic weight methods is to objectively determine the importance of each factor in reflecting human activity intensity, thereby ensuring a balanced and accurate assessment of human impact on the ecosystem.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are involved in determining the weights for various factors influencing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau pastoral area using entropy weight method?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological steps involve selecting factors that reflect human activity intensity, such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, cultivated land proportion, NDVI change rate, distance to roads, and distance to settlements. Entropy weight method is then used to determine the weights of these factors, which are combined through spatial overlay to obtain the human activity intensity datasets for different years.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data, specifically night-time light imagery, be processed and used to assess human activity differences across large-scale regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Night-time light imagery from remote sensing can be processed to capture visible light and near-infrared electromagnetic wave emissions under cloud-free conditions, which directly reflect differences in human activities. The data are then used in various applications such as urbanization process studies, impervious surface extraction, and socio-economic spatial estimation, supported by the advancement of new data products like NPP/VIIRS, which address previous limitations in spatial, temporal, and radiometric resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures for correcting the stable light imagery from DMSP/OLS to accurately estimate electric power consumption in large regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves an area correction for the stable light imagery using a cubic regression equation to address saturation issues in electric power supply areas. This involves analyzing the spatial distribution characteristics of the stable light and applying a regression between the corrected light data and statistical electric power consumption data, verified across multiple countries.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the accurate estimation of human activity intensity in regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the development of high-resolution night-time light data from the NPP/VIIRS and DMSP/OLS satellites have enabled the accurate estimation of human activity intensity in regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. These advancements address limitations in spatial, temporal, and radiometric resolutions, allowing for more precise monitoring of human activities.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple socio-economic and environmental factors enable a comprehensive assessment of human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Integration of multiple socio-economic and environmental factors, such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, arable land proportion, NDVI change rate, and distances to roads and settlements, enables a comprehensive assessment of human activity intensity. The use of entropy weight method to determine factor weights and spatial overlay techniques allows for the creation of detailed datasets reflecting human impacts over time.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to enable the effective use of night-time light data in evaluating long-term trends in human activity and environmental impact?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in using night-time light data include addressing arbitrary characteristics in dataset construction, such as limited sunlight influence periods and cloud cover assessments. Additionally, the need for systematic summarization and organization of research results to overcome limitations in coverage and timeliness is crucial for effectively evaluating long-term trends in human activity and environmental impact.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple factors, such as grazing intensity and night-time light index, be expected to enhance the accuracy of human activity intensity assessments in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau pastoral areas?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multiple factors like grazing intensity and night-time light index is expected to enhance the accuracy of human activity intensity assessments because these factors provide a comprehensive view of human impact. Each factor reflects different aspects of human activities, and their combined analysis can offer a more nuanced understanding of the intensity and distribution of human influence in ecologically sensitive areas like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why could the use of entropy weight method be anticipated to provide a more objective determination of factor weights in the assessment of human activity intensity?
Expectation.Answer: The entropy weight method could provide a more objective determination of factor weights because it relies on the variability and distribution of data rather than subjective judgment. This method quantitatively assigns weights based on the degree of disorder or uncertainty in the data, allowing for a more data-driven approach to evaluate the significance of each factor in assessing human activity intensity.

Judgmental.Question: How can entropy weighting method enhance the assessment of human activity intensity in ecological sensitive regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The entropy weighting method allows for a more objective determination of factor weights by evaluating the variation and importance of each factor reflecting human activity intensity. This method helps to accurately integrate diverse indicators such as population density, GDP density, and grazing intensity into a comprehensive assessment, which is crucial for understanding the impacts on fragile ecosystems like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the entropy weight method is used to determine the weights of different human activity intensity factors in data collection.
Assertion.Answer: The entropy weight method is employed to assign weights to various factors reflecting human activity intensity. It evaluates the diversity of information provided by each factor and determines the significance of each factor based on the amount of information it contributes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the techniques used to ensure the accuracy of night-time light data when assessing human activity intensity.
Assertion.Answer: Night-time light data is processed by correcting stable light imagery and addressing saturation issues through methodologies such as cubic regression equations. These techniques help to accurately estimate parameters like electric power consumption, which is indicative of human activity intensity.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss potential methodologies for integrating night-time light remote sensing data with socio-economic factors to improve the assessment of human activity impacts on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau ecosystem.
Request/Directive.Answer: Integrating night-time light remote sensing data with socio-economic factors could involve using advanced spatial analysis techniques to correlate light intensity with population density, GDP density, and other socio-economic indicators. This integration can be enhanced by leveraging machine learning algorithms to identify patterns and relationships, thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of human activity impacts on the ecosystem.
